fields.description: Commit to turning off all appliances in your room (computer, TVs, DVD players, game consoles) every night before you go to sleep. Appliances use a significant amount of electricity, so turning them off when you definitely won't be using them (like when you are asleep) will save energy.
fields.title: I will turn off all appliances every night before going to sleep

fields.description: Unplugging your electrical appliances when they are not in use prevents them from drawing power.
fields.title: I will unplug all electrical appliances when I am not using them

fields.description: Commit to turning off the lights when leaving any room.
fields.title: I will turn off the lights when leaving any room

fields.description: Refrigerators use lots of energy.  Sharing refrigerators means that the other does not have to be used.
fields.title: I will share a refrigerator with my roommate

fields.description: Commit to using task lighting (like a desk lamp) instead of overhead room lights when possible. Often overhead lights provide more light than you need, or might not provide the light where you need it. Using a desk lamp will reduce your electricity use while giving you the light you need, where you need it.
fields.title: I will use task lighting instead of overhead lights

fields.description: A vampire load is a device that uses power when plugged in, even when it is turned off and not doing anything. Commit to turning off any vampire loads (cell phone charger, iPod charger, game consoles, TVs) using a power strip when you are not using them, thereby saving energy.
fields.title: I will turn off vampire loads using a power strip

fields.description: Commit to turning off water at sinks when you aren't actually using the water, such as when brushing your teeth, shaving, applying makeup, etc. Clean water is a valuable resource that shouldn't be wasted. Also pumping water from the ground into a building, heating it, and then treating the used water takes energy, so reducing the amount of water used saves energy.
fields.title: I will turn off water when brushing my teeth or shaving

fields.description: Commit to turning off water when showering except when actively rinsing off soap or shampoo. Clean water is a valuable resource that shouldn't be wasted. Also pumping water from the ground into a building, heating it, and then treating the used water takes energy, so reducing the amount of water used saves energy.
fields.title: I will turn off water when sudsing and scrubbing in shower

fields.description: Commit to using natural light from windows or outdoors instead of turning on electric lighting. This can mean opening shades instead of turning on the lights, and/or planning your day so that tasks that require light (like reading books, doing written homework) are done during the day.
fields.title: I will use natural light instead of electric lighting

fields.description: Commit to turning off your printer when you aren't actively printing something out. This will reduce electricity use, since printers draw some power if they are turned on even when they aren't printing.
fields.title: I will turn off printer when not printing

fields.description: Commit to using the stairs instead of elevators during your day, whenever that is feasible. Elevators use electricity, so by using the stairs you will save some energy. Also, using the stairs is good exercise!
fields.title: I will use stairs instead of elevator

fields.description: Commit to recycling all (recyclable) beverage containers at an appropriate location. Making things from recycled materials generally costs less and uses less energy than making them from raw materials.
fields.title: I will recycle all beverage containers

fields.description: Commit to not driving off-campus in a car by yourself. Try riding the bus (free using your U-PASS!), riding a bike, walking, driving a moped, or using a vehicle with 3+ occupants instead. Transportation fuel is a major use of energy and it generates a lot of greenhouse gases, so traveling more efficiently saves energy and the planet.
fields.title: I won't drive off-campus alone

fields.description: Commit to using your TV (watching shows, movies, playing games) for not more than 1 hour per day. Widescreen TVs use a lot of electricity, so putting a limit on how much you use them will reduce your electricity use.
fields.title: I will limit my TV use to 1 hour a day

fields.description: Commit to always washing full loads of laundry. Washing less than a full load is less efficient, leading to more electricity and hot water being used per piece of laundry washed.
fields.title: I will wash only full loads of laundry

fields.description: Commit to wearing your Kukui Cup button every day during the commitment period. Wearing your button will help spread awareness about the competition, and remind others to get involved.
fields.title: I will wear my Kukui Cup button every day

fields.description: Commit to walking to any destination less than one mile away from your residence hall. Walking saves energy, costs nothing, and is good exercise.
fields.title: I will walk to destinations less than one mile away

fields.description: Commit to washing your laundry in cold water instead of warm or hot water. There are now detergents designed to be used in cold water, and it takes lots of energy to heat water up. By using cold water, you will be saving energy.
fields.title: I will wash my laundry in cold water

fields.description: Commit to measuring the length of your shower with a watch or phone, and reducing the time by 1 minute. Clean water is a valuable resource that shouldn't be wasted. Also pumping water from the ground into a building, heating it, and then treating the used water takes energy, so reducing the amount of water used saves energy.
fields.title: I will reduce my shower time by 1 minute

fields.description: Commit to turning off your music (from computer, stereo, etc) when you leave your room. You save electricity when you turn off your music when you aren't there to enjoy it.
fields.title: I will turn off my music when leaving my room

fields.description: Commit to turning off your computer/TV/game console and doing something that doesn't require electricity instead. There are many things you can do both on and off campus that don't require electricity, go find them!
fields.title: I will do something "unplugged" every day

fields.description: Commit to bringing and using reuseable bags when shopping instead of the paper or plastic ones offered by stores. Making disposable bags requires energy, and often the bags end up in our landfills or worse yet they blow away into the ocean. Using a reusable bag saves energy and keeps trash out of our landfills.
fields.title: I will bring reusable bags when shopping

fields.description: Commit to not eating any meat (beef, pork, chicken, fish, shellfish, etc) during the commitment period. Producing meat (beef in particular) uses a great deal of energy, and produces a great deal of greenhouse gasses. A vegetarian diet uses less energy and emits less greenhouse gas. There are many of vegetarian food options on campus, try them out!
fields.title: I will not eat meat

fields.question: What is the unit of measurement for household energy?
What is the unit of measurement for power?

fields.description:
What: Learn about the competition and the cool prizes you can win
When: September 30, 2010 7:00pm
Where: Roof lounge
fields.title: Attend Kukui Cup Orientation
fields.confirm_prompt: Enter the attendance code from the meeting.

fields.description: Watch episode 1 of "Be Energy Akamai!"
fields.title: Watch "Be Energy Akamai!, Episode 1"

fields.description: Attend the Blue Planet Foundation meeting.
fields.title: Attend Blue Planet Foundation Meeting
fields.confirm_prompt: Enter the ticket code provided at the meeting.

fields.description: Attend the Energy Pong Competition happening in your building.
fields.title: Attend the Energy Pong Competition
fields.confirm_prompt: Enter attendance code provided at meeting.

fields.description:
Find an incandescent bulb (perhaps from a desk lamp) and replace it with a CFL. You should throw away the incandescent bulb, because even though it isn't burned out it is a massive energy hog and you don't want someone using it later.

For verification, please take a photo showing both the incandescent bulb you replaced and the CFL you installed.
fields.title: Replace incandescent bulb with compact fluorescent (CFL)
fields.confirm_prompt: Please upload the photo you took, showing both the incandescent bulb you replaced and the CFL you installed.

fields.description: SustainableUH is a student-lead organization focused on establishing the University of Hawaii as a world leader in sustainable practices, education, and research. Attend a special meeting and find out what Sustainable UH has accomplished and how you can get involved!
fields.title: Attend SustainableUH meeting
fields.confirm_prompt: Enter the attendance code you received at the meeting.

fields.description:
Who Killed the Electric Car? is a 2006 documentary film that explores the creation, limited commercialization, and subsequent destruction of the battery electric vehicle in the United States, specifically the General Motors EV1 of the mid 1990s. The film explores the roles of automobile manufacturers, the oil industry, the US government, the Californian government, batteries, hydrogen vehicles, and consumers in limiting the development and adoption of this technology.

Showing in Room [?]
fields.title: Watch the movie "Who Killed the Electric Car?"
fields.confirm_prompt: Enter the attendance code you received at the movie.

fields.description:
[350.org](http://www.350.org/), a climate change advocacy organization, is organizing a series of "work parties" to take place on October 10, 2010 (10/10/10). Find a work party on the 350.org website and participate!

To verify your participation in the work party, please take a picture of the work going on.
fields.title: Participate in a 10/10/10 work party
fields.confirm_prompt: Please upload the image you took of the work party, and describe the work you did in the comments field.

fields.description:
Configure your computer and any external monitor to sleep after 20 minutes of inactivity. You can find instructions on enabling sleep functionality at the [EnergySTAR website](http://www.energystar.gov/index.cfm?c=power_mgt.pr_power_mgt_users).

Once you have changed your settings, please take a screenshot showing the new settings for use in verification:
  * [How to take a screenshot on Windows](http://www.wikihow.com/Take-a-Screenshot-in-Microsoft-Windows)
  * [How to take a screenshot on Mac OS X](http://www.wikihow.com/Take-a-Screenshot-in-Mac-OS-X)
fields.title: Configure computer to sleep after inactivity
fields.confirm_prompt: Please upload the screenshot you took of your new, more energy efficient system settings.

fields.description: Borrow the Kill-A-Watt power meter from your RA, and then for each plug-in appliances in your room, write down its energy consumption when turned on and when turned off. You might be surprised to learn how much power your stuff uses, even when turned off! When you are done, come back and type in your results to receive your points.
fields.title: Perform room energy audit
fields.confirm_prompt: List each plug-in device in your room, and how much power it uses when turned on, and when turned off.

fields.description: Become a member of your floor's team in the Energy Pong tournament for your residence hall.
fields.title: Play in Energy Pong tournament
fields.confirm_prompt: Enter in the attendance code you received from the Energy Pong referee.

fields.description:
Become a fan of the [Kukui Cup Competition group on Facebook](http://www.facebook.com/group.php?gid=101651363219833).

Once you have become a fan, take a screenshot of the Kukui Cup Facebook page for verification:
  * [How to take a screenshot on Windows](http://www.wikihow.com/Take-a-Screenshot-in-Microsoft-Windows)
  * [How to take a screenshot on Mac OS X](http://www.wikihow.com/Take-a-Screenshot-in-Mac-OS-X)
fields.title: Connect to Kukui Cup on Facebook
fields.confirm_prompt: Please upload the screenshot showing you joined the Kukui Cup Facebook group.

fields.description:
If you use [Twitter](http://twitter.com/), tweet a link to the [Kukui Cup website](http://dasha.ics.hawaii.edu:8100/) so other folks will learn about the competition.

Once you have tweeted, take a screenshot of the Kukui Cup Facebook page for verification:
  * [How to take a screenshot on Windows](http://www.wikihow.com/Take-a-Screenshot-in-Microsoft-Windows)
  * [How to take a screenshot on Mac OS X](http://www.wikihow.com/Take-a-Screenshot-in-Mac-OS-X)
fields.title: Tweet about Kukui Cup
fields.confirm_prompt: Please upload the screenshot showing your tweet about the Kukui Cup website.

fields.description:
Update your Facebook status with a link to the [Kukui Cup website](/) to promote the competition.

Once you have updated your status, take a screenshot for verification:
  * [How to take a screenshot on Windows](http://www.wikihow.com/Take-a-Screenshot-in-Microsoft-Windows)
  * [How to take a screenshot on Mac OS X](http://www.wikihow.com/Take-a-Screenshot-in-Mac-OS-X)

Foo!
fields.title: Link to Kukui Cup on Facebook status
fields.confirm_prompt: Please upload the screenshot showing a link to the Kukui Cup in your Facebook newsfeed.

fields.description:
This is a followup activity to the energy audit activity. If you haven't performed that activity, do it first and keep your notes around for this activity.

Based on the audit results, make a label for each device in your room that shows the number of watts consumed when on and off, located close to the power switch for those devices that have them.

Once you have made the labels take a photo of the devices with their labels on to be used for verification.
fields.title: Label appliance power requirements in your room
fields.confirm_prompt: Please upload the photo showing your labels on devices in your room.

fields.description: Use this [carbon footprint calculator](http://coolclimate.berkeley.edu/) to estimate the size of your carbon footprint. Record the size of your footprint for verification.
fields.title: Determine carbon footprint using calculator
fields.confirm_prompt: Enter in the carbon footprint you received from the calculator, and any comments you have about your carbon footprint.

fields.title: Inaugural Kukui Cup scheduled for October, 2010
fields.content: We expect this to be a great event and encourage participation.
fields.abstract:
Plans are under way to hold the first Kukui Cup competition in October, 2010!  We are currently working on installing power meters, developing the website, gathering educational resources, and refining the competition rules and structure.  

If you would like to get involved with planning of the competition, please contact Philip Johnson (<johnson@hawaii.edu>).

<object width="320" height="240"><param name="movie" value="http://www.youtube.com/v/vnPaLewMaAA&hl=en_US&fs=1&"></param><param name="allowFullScreen" value="true"></param><param name="allowscriptaccess" value="always"></param><embed src="http://www.youtube.com/v/vnPaLewMaAA&hl=en_US&fs=1&" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" allowscriptaccess="always" allowfullscreen="true" width="320" height="240"></embed></object>
Aloha! The Kukui Cup Competition will begin on Monday, October, 4th.
Energy Tip: Turn off the lights when you leave the room.

Commitments are a "pledge" or a "promise" that you will perform a simple task for your floor.  You can participate in up to 5 commitments.

A commitment must be performed for a few days before you can ask for points.  Beware, if you remove a commitment, then you will have to start all over again!

To request points for the commitment, simply click on the "Request Points" link.  There, you can enter an optional comment.  Then, your points are awarded immediately!

Goals are tasks that involve the participation of your fellow dorm floor residents.  A floor can only participate in up to 5 goals.  Also, each user can add up to two goals for their floor at a time.

To get points for completing a goal, you will need to click on the "Request Points" link.  There, you can enter an optional comment.  Once an admin approves your request, your entire floor will receive points.

Activities require you to perform some type of action, whether it's attending an event, participating in campus sustainability, or watching videos on energy conservation.  

To receive Kukui Nuts for the activity, click on the "Request Points" link.  To make sure that you have done the activity, you will be asked to either answer a question, provide a code, or upload a picture.

Once an admin approves your submission, you will receive your points!
This is a list of the activities you're currently participating in.
This is a list of the activities you can participate in.  Activities that you have already finished are not included in this list.

fields.text: The purpose of a Dorm Energy competition is to promote the importance of energy conservation with students residing in dorms, engaging them in an environmentally minded competition which is held between dorms. The competition is to educate students on simple things they can do to conserve energy while increasing their energy literacy. UH Dorm Energy Competition site

fields.title: Schools Engaging in Dorm Energy

fields.text: Since Hawaii is isolated from the U.S. mainland, its energy infrastructure and consumption is very unique among the rest of the United States.  Hawaii depends heavily on fossil fuels in order to meet its energy demands.  Since the state of Hawaii are fairly new islands that are situated in the most farthest reaches of the rest of the world, Hawaii geological structure is not capable of producing its own forms of fossil fuels.  Therefore, imported petroleum from Alaska and other foreign countries contribute to 90% of our energy production.
fields.title: Energy in Hawaii

fields.text:
We believe that the appropriate use and generation of energy is a critical issue for the future of Hawaii, and that the University of Hawaii must take a leadership role in education and research regarding this topic.

The University of Hawaii Dorm Energy website and the Kukui Cup is an initial step in a longer range project to provide all of Hawaii with information and incentives to implement positive, sustained changes in their energy behaviors.
fields.title: Why this website?

fields.text:
For more information about this website or the Kukui Cup competition, please contact:

Philip Johnson
Professor
Department of Information and Computer Sciences
University of Hawaii at Manoa
1680 East-West Rd, POST 307
johnson@hawaii.edu
fields.title: Contact info

fields.text:
This website provides resources and data related to energy usage in the University of Hawaii's residential housing.

It also supports the "Kukui Cup", an annual event designed to help residence hall members learn about energy, reduce their consumption, compete for prizes, and have fun!
fields.title: About This Site

fields.text: Cumulative plug load energy used by each dorm. The smaller the bar, the better!
fields.title: Dorm Energy Consumption

fields.text: The purpose of a Dorm Energy competition is to promote the importance of energy conservation with students residing in dorms, engaging them in an environmentally minded competition which is held between dorms. The competition is to educate students on simple things they can do to conserve energy while increasing their energy literacy. UH Dorm Energy Competition site
fields.title: What is it?

fields.text:
I tried to login with my UH account, but I could not!

Login facilities are available only to UH students currently living in three freshman residence halls (Hale Lehua, Hale Mokihana, and Hale Ilima). If you are not a current resident of those dorms, you will not be able to login even if you successfully provide your account credentials to the UH login service.

Additionally, login services to freshman residence hall residents are disabled until the competition starts in Fall, 2010.

What do you mean by "plug load"?

Currently, the meters in the residence halls only monitor the energy used by the wall outlets ("plug loads") on floors 3 through 12 (where residence rooms are located).

What do you mean by "baseline"?

Baseline refers to the "typical" levels of energy for a residence hall (or floors in the hall). We compute two baselines, one for energy and one for power.

In the case of power, we monitor the average power use for each of the 24 hours in a day over the course of several weeks. This results in 24 different baseline power levels for each residence hall (or floors in the hall). This is good because power values in the middle of the night are typically much lower than in the middle of the day, so the baseline comparison takes that into account.

In the case of energy, we monitor consumption over the course of several weeks, and use this to determine the baseline as an average energy consumption per day. This is good because energy consumption is shown as a cumulative value over longer periods of time, and so the baseline tends to even out short-term fluctuations in use.
fields.title: Frequently Asked Questions

fields.title: Sponsors

fields.text:
Motivation

One of the goals of the Kukui Cup is to learn more about the factors which help people to make sustained, positive changes to their energy behaviors.

Kinds of data collected

In order to accomplish this goal, we wish to collect and analyze data about your participation in the competition. This data takes two forms:
  1. Data collected from your interactions with this website. We will collect data about the things you do while logged in to this website, such as your activities, goals, and commitments. This helps us to understand which of these tasks are interesting and helpful.
  2. Data gathered through interviews and questionnaires. We will contact a subset of participants to request a short interview and/or to fill out an online questionnaire. This data will help us to understand more about the strengths and weaknesses of our approach.

Privacy

No identifying information about you will be made available in any research publications resulting from this study.

Note that as part of your participation in the competition, information such as your "public commitments" will be made available to others via mechanisms such as the Kukui Cup "wall" in your home page. If you choose to enable Facebook integration, then public commitments and activities will be transmitted to Facebook. However, such identifying information will not be made available in future research publications.

If you do not wish to participate

Your participation in this study is voluntary. If you decide you do not wish to participate in this study at any time, please contact Philip Johnson (johnson@hawaii.edu, 956-3489, POST 307, University of Hawaii). We will remove your data from all analyses.

You can decline to participate in this study but still participate in the Kukui Cup. Your decision to participate or not has no impact on your ablity to win prizes or participate in events associated with the competition.
fields.title: Terms and conditions

fields.text:
Commitments are a "pledge" or a "promise" that you will perform a simple task for your floor. You can participate in up to 5 commitments at a time.

A commitment must be performed for a few days before you can ask for points. Beware, if you remove a commitment, then you will have to start all over again!

To request points for the commitment, simply click on the "Request Points" link. There, you can enter an optional comment. Then, your points are awarded immediately!

[View Commitments](/activities/commitment_list/)
fields.title: Commitments

fields.text:
Activities require you to perform some type of action, whether it's attending an event, participating in campus sustainability, or watching videos on energy conservation.

To receive Kukui Nuts for the activity, click on the "Request Points" link. To make sure that you have done the activity, you will be asked to either answer a question, provide a code, or upload a picture.

Once an admin approves your submission, you will receive your points!

[View Activities](/activities/activity_list/)
fields.title: Activities

fields.text:
Goals are tasks that involve the participation of your fellow dorm floor residents. A floor can only participate in up to 5 goals. Also, each user can add up to two goals for their floor at a time.

To get points for completing a goal, you will need to click on the "Request Points" link. There, you can enter an optional comment. Once an admin approves your request, your entire floor will receive points.

[View Goals](/activities/goal_list/)
fields.title: Goals

fields.text:
Individual and group competitions

The Kukui Cup actually consists of two types of competitions: individual competitions and group competitions.

In an individual competition, you compete to accumulate the most "Kukui Nut" points by performing various actions, including activities, goals, and commitments. To win in the individual competition, you simply have to accumulate the most Kukui Nut points.

In a group competition, pairs of floors compete as a unit. Each dorm is divided into five groups consisting of floors 3-4, 5-6, 7-8, 9-10, and 11-12. To win in the group competition, your group must reduce its energy consumption more than other groups. To simplify things, whenever we refer to "floor" in this competition, we really mean "pair of floors".

Competition timeline and rounds

The competition will be held for three weeks starting in October, 2010. The official start date will be announced soon.

To provide multiple chances to win, the competition is divided into two week-long "rounds" as well as an overall "grand prize" round.

After the first week of competition, the winners of "Round 1" will be announced based upon those individuals who accumulated the most Kukui Nut points and those floors who reduced their energy consumption the most.

After the second week of competition, the winners of "Round 2" will be announced. Round 2 winners are based only on data from the second week of the competition.

After the third week of competition, the "Grand Prize" winners will be announced. The Grand Prize winners are based upon all three weeks of data.

How to win!

To compete for individual prizes, you first have to login to this website using the link at the upper right corner. Only members of the dorms competing in this competition are able to login.

Once you have logged in, you can collect points by (a) performing activities, (b) making public commitments, or (c) participating in floor-level goals.

The competition provides a wide variety of activities that you can participate in, such as watching videos, reading articles, attending workshops, or movies, or other events. Each time you complete an activity, you submit it for points. As part of this process, there is a simple verification procedure. For example, in the case of an activity that involves watching a certain YouTube video, the verification procedure might involve you answering a simple question about the contents of the video. In the case of an event, you will find a Kukui Cup administrator at the event who can give you a personalized code that verifies your attendance. Each activity earns you from 5 to 20 points.

Another way to earn points is by making public commitments, such as "I will turn off the lights after leaving a room". Each commitment lasts for five days, and you are limited to five commitments at any one time. We do not verify your commitments, and each commitment (when completed after the five days) is worth 2 points. Making a commitment is "public" in that it shows up on your Kukui Cup "wall" and on the electronic billboard associated with this competition.

A final way to earn points is through goal setting. Goals are different from activities and commitments in that they always involve the entire floor. For example, one goal might be to reduce the floor's energy consumption by 5% over five days. When a goal is achieved, every member of the floor gets Kukui Nut points. Goals are worth between 5 and 10 Kukui Cup points.

In addition to prizes for the most points, the competition will also award prizes to the floor that reduces their energy consumption the most. To do that, you simply have to learn how to conserve energy! As that is the goal of the activities, commitments, and goals, we believe that you will naturally learn how to save energy as you take part in this competition.

Award categories and prizes

Round 1 Awards:
CategoryAward
Individual on each floor who gained the most points. $25 gift certif.
Floor that gained the most points (across all dorms). Ice cream party
Floor that reduced energy use the most (across all dorms). Ice cream party

Round 2 Awards:

CategoryAward
Individual on each floor who gained the most points. $25 gift certif.
Floor that gained the most points (across all dorms). Ice cream party
Floor that reduced energy use the most (across all dorms). Ice cream party

Grand Prize Awards:

CategoryAward
Individual per dorm with highest number of points. iPod touch
Floor with highest number of points. Pizza party
Floor that reduced energy use the most. Pizza party

In the event of ties...

In the event that two or more individuals (or floors) are tied for the most points, then the timestamp associated with the final goal, commitment, or activity associated with the individuals (or floors) will be used to break the tie. In other words, the individual (or floor) who got to their final point total first will be declared the winner. Under the remote possibility that the final timestamps are equal, a coin toss will be used to decide the winner.

Given that energy consumption is measured down to a fraction of a watt-hour, we do not anticipate that any floor could tie with respect to their consumption. In case that this does occur, a coin toss will be used to decide the winner.
fields.title: Rules of the competition
